text:
We are able to convert food waste into biodiesel
and our production cost is 70 odd cents a liter.

Typically what waste water contains
is of course human waste. So this could be

liquid waste and solid waste produced from
the human body. So essentially urine and fecal

material. We primarily go after the carbon
content of these different waste streams and

we convert that carbon into energy. In the
US if you take a national average per capita

per day we produce 100 waste gallons of wastewater
per capita per day of which we drink only

2 liters, or 2 to 4 liters per day.
we chose biodiesel as a potential end product

because biodiesel can be used very widely.
In fact biodiesel can be used if in an automotive

setting biodiesel can be used in regular diesel
engines with little or no modifications.

In many countries the problem is lack of locally
available energy 24/7. This is reality.

A lot of times these systems are limited by
the energy that is available for them to clean

up the fecal substances, clean up the waste
water. And when energy like this is not available,

what happens is people donâ€™t have access to sanitation.
So, what we are doing is, we are not competing

with the biodiesel industry, we are not here
to compete with the fuel industry. All we

want to do is make enough energy to run a
sanitation system. And that energy we would

like to be produced locally, potentially running
on the energy completely that is running internally,

or partially, so we are not importing as much
energy anymore.
